frog::sys::ArgumentNullException

ArgumentNullException Class Reference

#include <ArgumentNullException.h>

Inheritance diagram for ArgumentNullException:

List of all members.

Detailed Description

This exception is thrown when a null reference is passed to a method that does not accept it as a valid argument.

See also:
ArgumentOutOfBounds

Inherits from:

      IllegalArgumentException

virtual const char* getDescription (   )  const throw () [inline, virtual, inherited]

uint32_t hashCode (   )  const throw () [virtual, inherited]
 

Returns a 32-bit hash code for the object.

This returns distinct integers for distinct objects. This is typically implemented by converting the internal address of an object into an integer, but this implementation technique is not required. Note that two objects are "the same" if their hash codes are equal.

bool sameObject (  const Object *  objA,
const Object *  objB
)  throw () [static, inherited]
 

Indicates whether some other object is the same as another object.

The term "same object" means both objects have the same hash code. These objects are considered "the same" if their hash codes are equal.

Parameters:
[in] objA The first object to compare.
[in] objB The second object to compare.
Returns:
Returns true if
  • objA is the same as the
  • objB and vice-versa; false otherwise.

bool sameObject (  const Object *  obj  )  const throw () [virtual, inherited]
 

Indicates whether some other object is the same as this one.

The term "same object" means both objects have the same hash code. Note that it is necessary to override the hashCode() function whenever this function is overriden, so as to maintain the general contract for the hashCode() function, which states that two objects are the same if their hash codes are equal.

Parameters:
[in] obj The object with which to compare.
Returns:
Returns true if this object is the same as the
  • obj argument; false otherwise.

virtual std::string toString (   )  const throw () [inline, virtual]
 

Returns the textual representation of the current object.

In general, the toString function returns a string that "textually represent" the object. The result should be a concise but informative representation that is easy for a person to read. It is recommended that all subclasses override this method otherwise it can be misleading if this function is called on a sublcass of Object.
